importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date of Trump's recent phone call with Putin, which preceded the announcement of a planned summit in Hungary and set the context for the subsequent cancellation of meetings.
This is the date of the previous Trump-Putin summit in Alaska, where key positions on ceasefire conditions were established and remain a reference point for current negotiations.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: This timeframe was initially proposed by Trump for a Trump-Putin meeting in Hungary, but has now been officially dismissed by both US and Russian officials as being infeasible.

keyTakeAways: There are no plans for a Trump-Putin summit in the near future, as confirmed by both the US White House and the Kremlin.
The planned meeting in Hungary, initially announced by Trump after a phone call with Putin on October 16, has been canceled due to diverging positions on ceasefire conditions.
Russia has demanded control of Ukraine's entire Donbas region, which conflicts with Trump’s position of freezing the current battle lines.
The US has expressed concern that Moscow is maintaining a 'maximalist' stance, while Russia maintains that its positions from the Alaska summit remain unchanged.
A preparatory phone call between US Foreign Minister Marco Rubio and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov was held, but an in-person meeting was deemed unnecessary.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and European leaders have criticized Russia’s stalling tactics, asserting that only Ukraine is genuinely committed to peace.
Putin has rejected multiple ceasefire proposals and insists on territorial concessions, which Kyiv views as unacceptable.
A meeting between Putin and Zelenskyy has been ruled out by the Kremlin until a peace deal is practically agreed upon.

namedEntities.name: Vladimir Putin
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Putin is the key decision-maker in Russia's peace proposals and has maintained a hardline stance on ceasefire conditions, including territorial demands, which directly contradicts Trump’s position.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump is central to the discussion of a potential Trump-Putin summit, and his position of freezing battle lines has become a focal point for negotiations, though it has been met with resistance from Moscow.

namedEntities.name: Marco Rubio
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: US Secretary of State (or Foreign Minister)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rubio is a key US diplomatic figure who engaged in a phone call with Russia's Foreign Minister, highlighting the US side’s efforts to coordinate and manage diplomatic efforts.

namedEntities.name: Sergey Lavrov
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Lavrov represents Russia’s official position on ceasefire demands and has affirmed that Russia’s stance from the Alaska summit remains unchanged, adding credibility to Moscow’s position.

namedEntities.name: Volodymyr Zelenskyy
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Zelenskyy is a central figure in the Ukrainian peace initiative and has publicly criticized Russia’s stalling tactics, emphasizing Ukraine’s commitment to peace.

namedEntities.name: Hungary
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hungary was proposed as a location for a Trump-Putin summit, but the plan has been abandoned due to lack of alignment on ceasefire conditions.

namedEntities.name: Alaska
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Alaska summit in August 2025 established initial ceasefire conditions and remains a reference point for current negotiations, with both sides citing its outcomes as foundational.

namedEntities.name: Donbas region
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Russia’s demand for control over the entire Donbas region is a major point of contention, directly conflicting with Trump’s freeze-of-battle-lines proposal.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A planned Trump-Putin summit in Hungary, initially announced after a phone call on October 16, has been canceled by both the US White House and Russian officials. The delay stems from fundamental disagreements over ceasefire conditions—Russia demands full control of Ukraine’s Donbas region and dismantling of Ukrainian military capabilities, while Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy advocate for freezing current battle lines. Despite a prior phone call between US and Russian foreign ministers, no further in-person meetings are planned. Both sides maintain that their positions from the August Alaska summit remain unchanged, though the US and European leaders criticize Russia’s maximalist stance and stalling tactics. The situation underscores growing diplomatic deadlock and the lack of progress toward a sustainable ceasefire in Ukraine.
title: ‘No plans’ for Trump-Putin summit in near future, officials say
